Award.AwardTitle: Temporal Variations in Hydrothermal Fluid Chemistry at 9-10N East Pacific Rise: Elucidating Ties to Crustal and Biological Processes
Award.AbstractNarration: This is a study of the hydrothermal systems at the Ridge 2000 East Pacific Rise Integrated Studies site at 9 degrees north. During the past decade pronounced temporal variability in the hydrothermal fluids have been observed, and the chemical data have been interpreted to suggest that the changes in fluid composition reflect changes in the depth of hydrothermal circulation. Three hypotheses will be addressed in the current project. Changes in the depth of phase separation reflect changes in depth to the heat source. Magma has migrated upward and will soon erupt and/or result in another diking event. Changes in fluid compositions, reflecting changes in the pressure-temperature conditions of reaction and phase separation, are the causes of changes in the biological communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is a study of the hydrothermal systems at the Ridge 2000 East Pacific Rise Integrated Studies site at 9 degrees north. The project was conceptualized based on previously observed pronounced temporal variability in the hydrothermal fluids. These chemical data had been interpreted to suggest that the changes in fluid composition reflect changes in the depth of hydrothermal circulation and that an eruption might be imminent. Indeed, during this project time period (in 2005/2006), an eruption along this segment of the East Pacific Rise did occur. During the project period, four cruises were completed, under the original PI’s (the late Professor Karen Von Damm’s) direction. On these cruises, over four hundred fluid samples were collected, nearly ninety low-temperature (or diffuse-flow) fluids and approximately three hundred fifty high temperature fluids. Dissolved fraction major ion chemical compositions for the 9°N fluids have been analyzed, and, subsequently, end member fluid compositions for the major ions have been calculated. A comparison of pre- and post- eruptive fluid compositions demonstrate that the vapors (fluids with chlorine contents less than that of seawater) were common after both the 1991/1992 and the 2005/2006 eruptions. Similarly, the temperature traces for the fluids showed the biggest diversions following the eruptions before returning to a state of equilibrium. Distinctive chemical signatures from closely juxtaposed vents (and on occasion even closely spaced orifices within the same vent) are a manifestation of a highly complex plumbing system. The relatively small variations in chemistry of discrete samples collected over a long time series demonstrate some vents preserve distinctive chemical signatures over substantial periods of time (~ 10 years). Time-series data, coupled with models defining the pressures and temperatures of fluid-rock equilibration, provide insight into fluid circulation depth and proximity to the heat source and changes over time in these key parameters. Specifically, there is a systematic variation north-to-south in the vent field fluid chemistry with respect to the events leading up to the eruption. In the vents north of 9 50’N, fluid chemical signatures (specifically chloride and silica contents) are consistent with a shoaling of the heat source, and, by inference, plumbing system. For vents to the south, the pressure-temperature implications of the fluid chemical data show just the opposite: a deepening of the fluid-basalt equilibration. These inferences from the hydrothermal fluid chemical signatures are broadly consistent with the eruption of lavas as defined in previous studies (e.g., Soule et al., 2007).

References cited

Soule, SA, et al. “New insights into mid-ocean ridge volcanic processes from the 2005-2006 eruption of the East Pacific Rise, 9 46’N-9 56’N.” Geology 35 (2007): 1079-1082.


Von Damm K.L. (2004) Evolution of the Hydrothermal System at East Pacific Rise 9 50’N: Geochemical Evidence for Changes in the Upper Oceanic Crust, The Thermal Structure of thee Oceanic Crust and the Dynamics of Hydrothermal Circulation, AGU Monograph, C. German, J. Lin and L. Parson (eds).
